Just the live virtual lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how words and pictures are used in tandem with powerful storytelling--in a variety of formats! I also learned some art history, as well as some comic techniques such as aspect-to-aspect, panel bleed, additive/parallel words and images, etc.

So many! I learned about the history of art. I learned how to critique others art, and I got to enjoy some really spectacular art made by my peers. I got to make art for myself and push my artistic boundaries.
I'm a lot happier with my art skills now, and I feel like I was exposed to a lot of methods of art which is exactly what I was looking for in this course.
how to read critically, analyze works of art, make art
Analyzing, critiquing, and improving art.
I learned about visual structure, conventions and strategies for storytelling in comics, and how words and pictures work together effectively to create meaning.

This course enabled me to practice and refine important group skills like offering constructive criticism and discussion with peers. I was also encouraged to explore new mediums to create works of art.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course would have been awesome if not for COVID-19. Strengths: Meaningful discussions about art history, getting to see my classmates' drawings, insightful advice on my work from the professor. Weaknesses: Towards the end of the semester the critiques from classmates were mostly positive, I definitely would have appreciated more criticism on how to improve my art.

The strengths of the class are the quality of the assignments and the professor. My classmates were also great. The weakness is the length of each period. Almost 2h30. This felt too long for me over Zoom.

I loved the low class size and it really felt like a little community by the end of the course. Professor Rodman offered wonderful comments and I think his passion was very present. The only weakness is that I wished there was a bit more constructive criticism in the class for our own pieces.

strengths: lots of engagement, manageable workload, interesting readings
improve: more feedback on assignments, varied readings
It's a great course but I would've liked more focus on practical artistic technique, rather than talking about mostly theoretical concepts.
This course offered readings that correlated well with assigned work, and there was a good balance between expression of creativity and the exploration and discussion of new ideas.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class would have been so awesome in person! As it was, it was still a great class, and the breaks in between definitely helped. I could tell during the critiques that some people were getting less engaged, especially towards the end of the semester, but Zoom fatigue probably contributed more than anything else to that.
Sharing our art over Zoom went better than expected. Everyone was able to display their screen and take us through their drafts or references.

It was a bit difficult taking this class remotely, especially since seeing the art we're discussing is such a large part of the course, but I would say that it was conducted as best it could under these circumstances.

I think it's very difficult to move this class online. That being said, I felt that this was the best option with having two classes for going over material and going over projects. I can't think of anything that would make this class better for an online format. Maybe they could try breakout rooms over zoom to get more personalized advice?
success: understanding of students' diff backgrounds, accommodation, breaks, and the online format for submission of assignments

I think using Box this semester to upload our work before class and also show things like process photos and extra notes really helped give us more of an experience with each other's artwork since we couldn't be in person. We also had virtual trips to libraries that worked out pretty well, so I still felt it was engaging over zoom.
Although discussion and communication were not hindered, I felt that the virtual format inhibited my overall engagement with the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Professor Halsey is a great professor and truly cares about what he's teaching. There's no need to have prior experience in art. The assignments every week are a great way to take a different kind of break while expressing yourself. You also learn to think more critically about the media surrounding you.
I would certainly recommend this course. Halsey Rodman is a wonderful instructor and artist. You will get to make some really great art, and get to see your peers grow in their art works, too.
Yes, but more so if you are interested in creating art weekly. If not, the weekly assignments can get a bit tedious and tiring. Otherwise, it was a fun and engaging class to take!
Yes! It was everything I was looking for in an introductory art course. I had never taken an art class before, but I loved how supportive the entire class felt.
Yes, a great introduction to the art department and art in general!
Yes. It's a great class for people who are both interested or unsure about visual arts.

Yes!! Absolutely. You don't have to have any previous experience with art and the class atmosphere was always really encouraging. I loved seeing all my classmates with different academic interests/majors show their creativity through so many different mediums, and in a way it really made me remember why I liked art classes so much when I was younger. I feel like I haven't been in a class that captured that feeling in a long time, so I was really grateful to take this as my first-year seminar. The graphic novels we got to read were also super cool, and I'm inspired to work on my own comics for fun in the future.
Yes
Yes, I think that this course is a great introductory art class that also offers reading and group related skills that can be applied to other classes.
